response.answer_text: Who would have thought I could revive someone who was about to leave this world. No medical training, not good with the sick. I’m on holiday with a male friend, we had driven from my home the previous day staying overnight en route, had dinner and an early night. Having driven the second day since breakfast, stopping for a quick bite for lunch we were both becoming weary mid afternoon within an hour of our destination. Our friends expected us late afternoon. We stopped to top up for fuel at a Caltex garage. I said “I’ll drive the remainder and give you a break should only be an hour away now”. “No need I’m a bit stiff from sitting but I’ll be okay, be back in a tick”. In the passenger seat waiting my eye caught a man running towards the fuel pumps, gesturing to someone, realising I was that someone as he stopped beside my car. “Quick come with me as he opened the door. Your husband/partner is having some kind of seizure, hurry come with me, quick, he repeated agitated! My heart gave a lurch, I ran after the attendant into the garage shop, people standing back giving me room to go to my friend. They told me he walked up to the counter, gave the attendant his card to pay, felt his brow briefly, then fell sideways hitting his head on the corner of the counter then the nearby food stand on his way down, then cracking his head on the tiles when he landed. He is a tall man 6′2″. He fell heavily. I saw blood pooling under his head. I was shocked as I knelt on the tiles beside him, his face colour was a weird blue/black kind of mottling, he was unconscious of course and dying. “I said he needs CPR can anyone help, I will give mouth to mouth. A man came forward he was of solid build, strong looking I suggested he began the CPR please” as I held my friends nose giving mouth to mouth to try and resusitate him. A woman Caltex staff member held his head for me. An off-duty nurse hearing a scream from a woman in the store came running from around the corner from a food counter. She called Emergency Services. The chap and I were working unaware of anything around us except my friend on the floor. Emergency services were telling the Nurse to advise us how we should continue doing what we were doing, help was on the way. There was an eerie quietness as the two of us keep up the breathing and CPR counting the only sound. There were quite a few people trying to enter the store to pay for their fuel, they were all asked to please wait outside, I was vagely aware of how everyone and everything was quiet around us as we worked away. We were still working on my friend when two ambulances turned up and the Paramedics tookover. When I stood up I was shaking badly, feeling exhausted, a little dizzy. I went to the Hospital in the second ambulance whilst the first Ambulance had raced away. I sat and waited for some news as my friend was being operated on, before long the cardiologist came to speak with me. “I’ve put two stents in your friend’s heart, he’s had a cardiac arrest, then two further heart attacks. You saved his life! He really shouldn’t be here”! He continued, “If it had happened on the motorway you both may not be alive right now. You did a good job, well done. I am surprised he is alive as he has two arteries fully blocked and half of his other artery is blocked, he was like a walking dead man.” There was a fear of brain damage once he came out of the induced coma in ICU as he’d had two further heart attacks whilst in the coma over the next week. He recovered okay eventually. When the Dr asked me how everything had unfolded at the garage I explained the colour of his skin on his face. The Dr said he was seconds from death, that is the colour of someone on their way out. I may not have described this colour correctly but I was aware he may have died had I and the kind gentleman who helped me had not acted as quickly as we had. We brought him back………….

Doctors have told me that medically, I should not be alive now. I technically ‘died’ twice in July, 2016. My heart stopped beating on July 13, 2016. Medics were able bring me back. The doctors wanted me to gain strength before they operated on my heart so they kept me in an Acute Care Unit, put me into a drug induced coma, and hooked me up to heart and lung bypass machines to keep me alive. I was not gaining strength and my kidneys were starting to fail. On July 20, 2106 (while still attached to the bypass machines) my heart stopped again. Medics were able to bring me back once again and they took me to surgery. After surgery, my kidneys shut down… I was now on heart and lung bypass machines as my heart was to weak pump blood, chest muscles too weak for me to breathe, and I was on 24 hour dialysis to bypass the kidneys. After I came out of the coma, August 20th, 2016, I asked the doctor how long I was without oxygen and all he said was that they were monitoring me for brain damage. I know I was without a pulse for a few minutes each time my heart stopped, and the closest durations that I can determine is July 13 was less than 10 minutes and July 20 was less than 5 minutes. Technically, I died twice – no pulse, not breathing, and kidneys shut down on second occurrence. It was very hard for me to accept that I died because I could see and hear the doctors, my wife, and others. So, how could I have died, and yet see and hear, when death is permanent? I do not think I reached the point of being brain dead, but, the doctors had told my wife that they would not be able to tell if I had suffered brain damage until after I regained conciseness. At first they were concerned as I could not remember anything since 2014. But, over a couple of weeks, I did recover most memory, but still cannot remember anything between July 4, 2016 and August 20, 2016. A physical indicator that showed I indeed died was that all of my fingernails had stopped growing each time that my heart stopped. I noticed the anomalies in December, 2016 and had a doctor look at my fingers. He verified that the thinning of my fingernails were due to new cells not being produced while I was ‘dead’ and that the growth rate of my fingernails was correct for a 5 month period to have elapsed.

I just want to point out that all the scientific explanations I’ve heard are, at best, circumstantial evidence in regard to the belief that the Human Brain is the SEAT of consciousness, and that consciousness does not and cannot exist without a brain and nervous system. Here’s the thing. All we REALLY know is that such brain phenomena happen at the same time as the experience of “consciousness.” This is hardly proof that the brain IS the seat of consciousness. That would be like saying that all human beings are computers because they all appear as electrical impulses on the computers connected to the internet. A measurable phenomenon that occurs completely simultaneously for sure, but NOT the same thing. My experience includes vivid memories of previous lives, as well as the “times” between physical incarnations. I remember it as “Home” and yes, there are times I get “homesick.” Of these events, some occurred with A brain present, but not my current brain, and some of them occurred in states where I had NO brain at all, yet I knew, I felt, I experienced, I observed. Interestingly, I have had a fair amount of corroboration from others, but the clincher for me was my youngest son. At the time, he really was just barely old enough to talk. I had been quite scrupulous about NOT attempting to guide or indoctrinate him in matters of spirituality, reincarnation, religion, life, death, all the good, juicy existential stuff. STILL, he began one day to tell me of his past lives. He had been a child in the two lives he remembered. He had died young in both cases, and he remembers the sadness and disappointment of betrayal from the parents who beat and killed him. He THEN began to talk about how he and his mom would play “catch” with an IMAGINARY Blue Ball of light when he was no more than 1 month old. My wife is an artist, and a very visual person. She most certainly DID do this with my infant son — she would mentally picture a glowing Blue Ball of light, and gently propel it toward the baby. He would catch it and toss it back, giggling the whole time. She told me about this at the time. No, I did NOT find it weird. Such things seem perfectly natural to me, based on my own life experience. It’s one of the things I love MOST about my beautiful wife. This time, though, we were stunned! Neither of us thought he would remember this, and of course there was always a shred of doubt that this exercise was anything more than an imaginary dalliance. See, that’s one of the challenges about visualization, manifestation, and any sort of clairvoyance — it feels like you are just making it up at the time. This is why so many people believe that it doesn’t exist. If you understand a little Quantum Physics, and/or Process Psychology or the Aussie Aboriginal Dreamtime experience, you will know that this is a piece of wisdom that has shown up in multiple situations throughout history. BUT, here is the corker. In this conversation with my son, he then went on to describe his experience of being “in that other place where everything is just LOVE, all the time” and wanting to reincarnate again. He said they offered him several choices of parents, but HE chose US. We are honored. He said they never had expectations or tried to influence his choice, but just blessed it all. Side note: My wife and I were VERY aware of the importance of choice in making a baby, and we had both “put it out there” that we wanted a truly amazing soul; an Old Soul for our child together. What can I say? IT WORKED!

No one can tell you that for certain. It may be true that the essence of one’s consciousness and personality is stored or maintained by electrical impulses in the brain. Alternatively, however, that might not necessarily be true. The brain is surely the instrument of reasoning and memory, but those are not all of which constitutes the individual. There are many people who believe that the individual is not anything electrical or biochemical, but that the essence of the individual is something evanescent, called the soul. Now, at the time of what we call death, the brain shuts down. All electrical activity ceases. Within a very short time, cellular decomposition begins. All the neural pathways break down, and the pattern of interconnection is irreversibly lost. It cannot be reconstructed, both because of the physical and biochemical complexity, and because there is no recording made of the previous organization and information storage in the brain. Hence if you believe that everything you are as an individual resides in your brain, you could never possibly be reconstructed after death. There is no known way, and most likely no possible way, of preserving a brain intact and functioning after death. Freezing, for example, would utterly destroy it, leaving only a pile of frozen meat. As an illustration, every so often a Wooly Mammoth is found frozen and intact somewhere in the far north — perhaps the victim of an ancient avalanche of snow, asphyxiated and flash-frozen. But science has no way of re-animating that creature. It is no more liable to be resuscitated than a frozen hamburger. If the individual is actually something that resides in a brain, and if in some manner that brain could be preserved electrically and chemically intact at the point of death to be later restored into functioning life, then there would have to be something going on in the preserved brain. We know that memory and reasoning are not a matter of static charges, but of the dynamic movement of electrical impulses — whether one is physically conscious or not. That being the case, imagine what might be happening in that preserved brain. One who has been deprived of senses, by death, would be dreaming or hallucinating. You might be having the most extreme possible nightmares inside that preserved brain, maybe hundreds or thousands of years of the screaming heebie-jeebies, with you not being able either to scream or to wake up. The eventual reconstituted human being would surely awaken, irrecoverably and irreversibly insane. I do not think you would like that. It is possible, however, that the individual is something other than a functioning brain. It may be that the personality and consciousness and memory are incorporated into what is called a soul. Many people, billions actually, believe that. And billions have believed that, over thousands of years gone by. Some of those who believe that humans have a soul, feel that it goes to some other place after death. Many feel that it is a place not within this physical universe, nor even anywhere that has the dimensionality of this universe. There are various names given to the place or places where departed souls are believed to transfer into. These include Heaven, Hell, Paradise, Hades, Valhalla, Nirvana, Underworld, World to Come, Asura, Purgatory, Tian, Good Kingdom, Moksha, Eden, New Jerusalem, Glory, Elysium, Gehenna, and many others. Some people, both now and over centuries past, feel that souls can return to earth and be reincarnated. A portion of those feel that human souls are reborn into other human bodies. A portion feel that human souls may be reborn into other creatures such as cows, dogs, monkeys, cockroaches, or bacteria. Most beliefs hold that a reconstituted soul does not retain conscious memories of prior existences. Some individuals, however, feel that prior memories may be responsible for sensations such as deja vu, or for one’s phobias, or for a particular sense of affiliation with certain other people. Some people believe prior memories can be reactivated through hypnotism or by great traumas or by magical spells. No one, except perhaps those who have already died, can say for certain what (if anything) actually occurs after death. Or whether there is any form of rebirth or reincarnation. No one can say whether it is like awakening, or whether it is a slow progression into self-awareness as happens with infants growing into children growing into adults. Some people feel that souls live on, but in a disembodied form such as ghosts. Others believe that souls return in their original form, except in a non-physical way, in which they inhabit their former homes in a way called haunting, where there are occasional viewings possible by the current residents. Yet others feel that souls remain near their loved ones, in a manner called presence, and can guide or protect or even speak to the living. You may choose to believe whatever you want. Or you can believe, as some do, that death is extinction of the individual, with no continuing consciousness; a total blackout. The majority of teachings, and religions, around the world and over the ages, suggest that one’s current life is neither the ultimate nor the end of one’s existence. While there are vast differences in views about what will happen or how it will happen after death, there has always been strong unanimity of opinion that the purpose and the value of one’s present life is to prepare for the next life, whatever that might be. Generally speaking, it is thought that appropriate preparation includes learning as much as possible, in as many areas as possible. It also includes doing good works or helping others or alleviating suffering of others. It also includes developing one’s relationships with others, learning such qualities as love, compassion, sharing or charity, self-sacrifice, selflessness, empathy, and honor. As it happens, learning and practicing these actions and qualities generally contributes greatly to the quality and happiness of one’s current life, quite aside from whatever it may or may not do after you die. So, both to give yourself a better life and as insurance to prepare yourself for another life should it occur, it is probably very smart to cultivate all of those.

There are a decent number of accounts of people who have “died” but came back and even made a full recovery. The problem though is that we actually still have a *very* nebulous concept of what “being dead” actually means. If your heart stops, there is still a period of time when your brain is still alive (specifically your cells are still viable and your memories have not begun to be erased from lack of oxygen). We actually don’t know for sure what the window for this is. Most of the time if a heart stops you have between eight and twelve minutes before permanent brain injury begins. Note that qualifier “most of the time.” Because there are documented cases of people being without a heartbeat for over an hour and still being revived with no discernible brain damage or memory loss. Usually there are other circumstances at play (children are more likely to be recover, or someone was dunked into freezing water and the severe cold may have slowed the process of decay, etc). Which still means there is a pretty much unknown window of time in which a person can still be brought back from this “death.” On the extreme end you may wind up with a vegetable but technically they are still “alive.” We basically don’t have a way to measure if a person is truly dead. Brain death doesn’t occur right away after the heart stops. Lack of brain activity is not a sure sign of death either. Failure of autonomic systems doesn’t necessarily mean dead (people have been brought back from that). I would hazard that most of the stories of people being “brought back from the dead” are people who weren’t actually dead to begin with. They were close to it, and were either brought back through medicine or their bodies somehow pulled back from the brink on their own.

Now, if I understand your question somewhat differently, the answer is different too. Many people believe that some part of a person will survive the death of the body and will continue in some form of spirit life. In broad Christian circles this part that survives is called the “soul.” However, understanding the Bible properly shows that this belief in a soul that continues to live in some form is a serious misunderstanding caused by the introduction of Greek philosophy into the early Christian church. The easiest way to see this is by going back to how the Bible records the origin of life. Right at the beginning of the Bible in the book of Genesis (a word that means ‘origin’) we learn that after creating the heavens and the earth (Genesis 1:1) God created the first couple of people, a man and a woman, Adam and Eve, on the 6th day (Genesis 1:26–27). How the creation of Adam was done is then further explained in Genesis 2:7 which tells us that “the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life” whereupon “man became a living being” ( or “a living soul” in some translations). Here we learn that a human person consists of two elements: a body made from chemicals available in the “dust of the ground”, and a life force that brings that body to life by giving it the process of breathing. Note especially that Genesis 2:7 does not say than man was given a “soul” or “being”, but that the combination of body and breath (life force) produced a “living being” or “living soul”. Thus it is clear: the soul is the being, the person. When a person dies the reverse process takes place. This is clearly stated in Psalm 104:29 (and in many other passages) where we read, “You [God] take away their [the living creatures’] breath, and they return to dust (words in [ ] inserted by me for clarification). The person dies. The body cannot live without the breath, and the breath (life force) cannot live without the body when it has no longer access to lungs and a heart. Note though, that is not the end of the story. The Bible also teaches us that there is a resurrection, a reunion of body and breath to create a new person now privileged to live eternally without ever seeing death again. The life, death, and resurrection of God’s Son Jesus Christ is the prime example of God’s beautiful plan to offer humanity new life when Jesus comes back from heaven (see John 11:23–24; Corinthians 15:51–54; 1 Thessalonians 4:13–17; Revelation 21:1–5, and many other texts). So, taking the long view of your question, the answer is YES. We can live (a long time) after we have died because God has made provision for all people to join Him for life eternal in a world made new where death and all kinds of misery will no longer be found, and life will be lived in the way it was originally intended to be lived.

The second category is nearly all people who went into cardiac arrest, and therefore some people say they “died” before their heart was shocked back into beating. But that’s not really death; actual death is when brain activity ceases (I would maintain this to be true even in people who are “brain dead” but whose bodies keep functioning due to artificial means). The brain can continue to function for some time even if the heart is stopped. And as long as it is still functioning, the person is not dead.

It’s not an easy question to answer in a binary sense. Death is a process. It is possible to be resuscitated at any point during that process (i.e. respiratory failure, heart failure, multiple organ shut down, brain death). *When* a person is resuscitated can determine their quality of life afterwards. For example, if someone’s heartbeat weakens to the point of stopping, but the hospital staff successfully gets it going again with the crash cart / paddles, it’s likely that there will be little to no lasting damage, especially compared to what would be if their respiration and heartbeat stopped for enough time to cut communication to the brain. Now, in terms of “after death”, I would say the answer is no. Once every life function has ceased down to even the most trivial functions of the brain, or those nervous reflexes not controlled by the brain (such as the Lazarus reflex- a rare phenomenon where a dead body will extend its arms and cross them over its chest), there is no returning as far as I know.
